title: New CCTV image released after racist messages taped to primary school, community centre and library
text:
News New CCTV image released after racist messages taped to primary school, community centre and library Police have released a security still of a man they want to speak to in connection with the hate crime Share Police want to speak to this man after racist messages were posted on community buildings in Longsight Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
A new CCTV image has been released after racist messages were taped to a primary school, community centre and library, and posted through doors. 
The offensive material, which police say wasn’t directed at any specific group, was distributed in south and east Manchester during the afternoon of Thursday, February 16. 
St Luke’s Primary School in Ardwick, Longsight library , the Pakistani Community Centre and households around the area were all targeted. 
Police have released a security still of a man they want to speak to in connection with the hate crime, after releasing a separate image on Saturday. 
The man was seen near St Luke’s at about 12.45pm on Thursday, and was spotted wearing a blue hoodie, black trousers and back pack. Police want to speak to this man in connection with a hate crime investigation in Longsight and Ardwick 
Superintendent Dave Pester from the City of Manchester Team, based at Longsight Police Station, said: “We are continuing our investigation to find out who is responsible for this despicable crime. 
“Hate crime has no place in our community and we will do all we can to catch the offender. 
“We have released another photo in a bid to identify a young man who was seen near to St Luke’s Primary School on the Coverdale Estate in Ardwick around 12.45pm on Thursday. Read More 
“Although the face of the person isn’t clear in the photo, I am hoping someone recognises them, perhaps by the clothes they are wearing, and if you do I urge you to contact us. 
“If you have had similar material posted through your door, please get in touch with police.” 
Anyone with information is asked to contact police on 101 quoting incident number 2293 16/02/17, or Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111. Like us on Facebook
